posts.post_content: I like that it's an azorius Magistrate stopping one of his OWN soldiers from using a spell, rather than one of the other guilds. They always say the Azorius are obstructive bureaucrats, but you never see them do it to themselves, even though that's what bureaucracy is supposed to do (stop itself).

posts.post_content:
Well... um...  
[Goblin Electromancer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Electromancer) at least lets you cast this for UU.  
  
Then again, he also lets you cast [Dissipate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dissipate) for UU and [Rewind](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rewind) for 1UU. Both of which are probably better choices than Cancel, and only Dissipate will see any real constructed play.

Posted By: ZephyrBlayze (9/26/2012 6:24:20 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Obviously this is strictly worse than Counterspell, and almost completely worse than Dissipate in our current format, but it is still a hard counter that is really good in casual and I think is underrated (though again, Dissipate is almost strictly better unless your meta has no graveyard manipulation). For control decks, even in Modern, I think having a hard counter outside the heavy color weighted Cryptic Command is important, as stuff like Mana Leak and even Rune Snag only goes so far in the late game. Rune Snag can hold its own pretty well when it works, but most two costed counterspells are fickle. Game 2 Negate can help mitigate that, but I think cards like this still have a place if you need a hard counter (as opposed to Mana Leak) that doesn't give them the pieces back (like Remand, which I think is better in something like WUR Delver).
posts.html:
Obviously this is strictly worse than Counterspell, and almost completely worse than Dissipate in our current format, but it is still a hard counter that is really good in casual and I think is underrated (though again, Dissipate is almost strictly better unless your meta has no graveyard manipulation). For control decks, even in Modern, I think having a hard counter outside the heavy color weighted Cryptic Command is important, as stuff like Mana Leak and even Rune Snag only goes so far in the late game. Rune Snag can hold its own pretty well when it works, but most two costed counterspells are fickle. Game 2 Negate can help mitigate that, but I think cards like this still have a place if you need a hard counter (as opposed to Mana Leak) that doesn't give them the pieces back (like Remand, which I think is better in something like WUR Delver).

posts.post_content:
This is still a strong spell, but people want their counters to be ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol) mana. Wizards has decided hardcounters at ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) are not going to be printed unless they are given a drawback ([deprive](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=deprive)).  
  
Dissipate outclasses this, but you would still would want to use this over dissipate if you had things like [Rise from the Grave](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rise from the Grave) in your deck. Also you could run x4 of this and dissipate.
posts.html:
This is still a strong spell, but people want their counters to be mana. Wizards has decided hardcounters at are not going to be printed unless they are given a drawback (deprive).

Dissipate outclasses this, but you would still would want to use this over dissipate if you had things like Rise from the Grave in your deck. Also you could run x4 of this and dissipate.
